sen.j: 福地 源一郎（ふくち げんいちろう、1841年5月13日（天保12年3月23日_(旧暦)） - 1906年1月4日）は、幕末の幕臣、明治時代のジャーナリスト、作家、劇作家。
sen.e: Genichiro FUKUCHI (May 13, 1841-January 4, 1906) was Shogun's retainer at the end of the Edo period and a journalist, writer and playwright in the Meiji period.
Genichiro FUKUCHI (May 13, 1841-January 4, 1906) was Shogun's retainer in the end of the Edo period and a journalist, writer and playwright in the Meiji period.
Genichiro FUKUCHI (May 13, 1841-January 4, 1906) was Shogun's retainer in the end of the Edo period and a journalist, writer and playwright in the Meiji period.

sen.j: 幼名は八十吉（やそきち）。
sen.e: His childhood name was Yasokichi.
His childhood name was Yasokichi.
His childhood name was Yasokichi.

sen.j: 号は櫻癡（おうち、新字体：桜痴）。
sen.e: His go (byname) was Ochi.
His go (byname) was Ochi.
His go (byname) was Ochi.

sen.j: 福地 桜痴（ふくち おうち）として知られる。
sen.e: He is known as Ochi FUKUCHI.
He is known as Ochi FUKUCHI.
He is known as Ochi FUKUCHI.

sen.j: 生涯
sen.e: Biography
Biography
Biography

sen.j: 1841年、長崎で医師福地苟庵の息子として誕生した。
sen.e: In 1841 he was born as a son of Dr. Koan (苟庵) FUKUCHI in Nagasaki.
sen.cmt: 苟庵の読み方不明です。
sen.e: In 1841 he was born as a son of Dr. Koan (苟庵) FUKUCHI in Nagasaki.
In 1841 he was born as a son of Dr. Koan (苟庵) FUKUCHI in Nagasaki.

sen.j: 長崎で蘭学を学び、1857年に海軍伝習生の矢田堀景蔵に従って江戸に出た。
sen.e: He studied Western learning at Nagasaki and went to Edo in 1857, following Keizo YATABORI who was a learner of navy.
He studied Western learning in Nagasaki and went to Edo in 1857, following Keizo YATABORI who was a learner of navy.
He studied Western learning in Nagasaki and went to Edo in 1857, following Keizo YATABORI who was a learner of navy.

sen.j: 以後、2年間ほどイギリスの学問や英語を森山栄之助の下で学んだ。
sen.e: After that, he had studied leanings of U.K. and English under Einosuke MORIYAMA for two years.
After that, he had studied leanings of U.K. and English under Einosuke MORIYAMA for two years.
After that, he had studied leanings of U.K. and English under Einosuke MORIYAMA for two years.

sen.j: そして、外国奉行支配通弁御用雇として、翻訳の仕事に従事することとなった。
sen.e: Then he was in charge of translation as Gaikoku bugyo shihai tsuben goyoyatoi (an interpreter of the magistrate of foreign affairs).
Then he was in charge of translation as Gaikoku bugyo shihai tsuben goyoyatoi (an interpreter of the magistrate of foreign affairs).
Then he was in charge of translation as Gaikoku bugyo shihai tsuben goyoyatoi (an interpreter of the magistrate of foreign affairs).

sen.j: 1861年、1865年には幕府の使節としてヨーロッパに赴き、西洋世界を視察した。
sen.e: In 1861 and 1865 he visited Europe as a member of the envoy of bakufu and observed the Western world.
In 1861 and 1865, he visited Europe as a member of the envoy of bakufu and observed the Western world.
In 1861 and 1865, he visited Europe as a member of the envoy of bakufu and observed the Western world.

sen.j: ロンドンやパリで刊行されている新聞を見て深い関心を寄せた。
sen.e: He was deeply interested in newspapers published in London and Paris.
He was deeply interested in newspapers published in London and Paris.
He was deeply interested in newspapers published in London and Paris.

sen.j: 福地は江戸城開城後の1868年閏4月（旧暦）に江戸で「江湖新聞」を創刊した。
sen.e: Fukuchi launched 'Koko Shinbun' at Edo on leap April 1868 after the surrender of Edo Castle.
Fukuchi launched 'Koko Shinbun' in Edo on leap April 1868, after the surrender of Edo Castle.
Fukuchi launched 'Koko Shinbun' in Edo on leap April 1868, after the surrender of Edo Castle.

sen.j: 翌月、彰義隊が上野で敗れた後、同誌に「強弱論」を掲載し、以下のように厳しく述べた。
sen.e: After shogitai (group of former Tokugawa retainers opposed to the Meiji government who fought in the Battle of Ueno) was defeated at Ueno on the following month, he announced 'Kyojakuron' (A theory of the strong and the weak) on that paper and described severely as 'Although it is said that the society became better or this is the Meiji Restoration, it is only a change of government from bakufu to Saccho (the Satsuma clan and the Choshu clan). It is really just an appearance of another bakufu led by Saccho instead of (Edo) bakufu.'

After shogitai (group of former Tokugawa retainers opposed to the Meiji government who fought in the Battle of Ueno) was defeated at Ueno in the following month, he announced 'Kyojakuron' (A theory of the strong and the weak) on that paper, severely saying as follows.
sen.cmt: 分割例に従い分割しました。前置詞変更しました。
sen.e: After shogitai (group of former Tokugawa retainers opposed to the Meiji government who fought in the Battle of Ueno) was defeated at Ueno in the following month, he announced 'Kyojakuron' (A theory of the strong and the weak) on that paper, severely saying as follows.

sen.j: 「ええじゃないか、とか明治維新というが、ただ政権が幕府から薩長（薩摩藩と長州藩）に変わっただけではないか。」
sen.e: Although it is said that the society became better or this is the Meiji Restoration, it is only a change of government from bakufu to Saccho (the Satsuma domain and the Choshu domain).'
sen.cmt: 分割例に従い分割しました。藩の表現変更しました。
sen.e: Although it is said that the society became better or this is the Meiji Restoration, it is only a change of government from bakufu to Saccho (the Satsuma domain and the Choshu domain).'

sen.j: 「ただ、幕府が倒れて薩長を中心とした幕府が生まれただけだ。」
sen.e: It is really just an appearance of another bakufu led by Saccho instead of (Edo) bakufu.'
sen.cmt: 分割例に従い分割しました。
sen.e: It is really just an appearance of another bakufu led by Saccho instead of (Edo) bakufu.'

sen.j: これが新政府側の怒りを買い、新聞は発禁処分となった。
sen.e: This made the new government get angry and the newspaper was prohibited to be published.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This made the new government get angry and the newspaper was prohibited to be published.
This made the new government get angry and the newspaper was prohibited to be published.

sen.j: 福地は逮捕されたが、木戸孝允が取り成したため、無罪放免とされた。
sen.e: Fukuchi was arrested but released because Takayoshi KIDO made an intercession.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Fukuchi was arrested but released because Takayoshi KIDO made an intercession.
Fukuchi was arrested but released because Takayoshi KIDO made an intercession.

sen.j: 明治時代初の言論弾圧事件である。
sen.e: This was the first incident of suppression of free speech in the Meiji period.
This was the first incident of suppression of free speech in the Meiji period.
This was the first incident of suppression of free speech in the Meiji period.

sen.j: 1870年、大蔵省に入り、翌年岩倉使節団の一等書記官として各国を訪れた。
sen.e: In 1870 he entered Okura-sho (Ministry of the Treasury) and in the following year he visited various countries as a first secretary of Iwakura Mission.
In 1870, he entered Okura-sho (Ministry of the Treasury) and in the following year, he visited various countries as the first secretary of Iwakura Mission.
sen.cmt: コンマ挿入、冠詞変更しました。
sen.e: In 1870, he entered Okura-sho (Ministry of the Treasury) and in the following year, he visited various countries as the first secretary of Iwakura Mission.

sen.j: 帰国後の1874年、政府系の東京日日新聞に入社し（主筆、のち社長）、ジャーナリストとして大いに筆名を上げた。
sen.e: After he came back to Japan, in 1874, he entered a government-controlled newspaper company, Tokyo Nichinichi Newspaper (main writer, and later president) and became very famous as a journalist.
After he came back to Japan, in 1874, he entered a government-controlled newspaper company, Tokyo Nichinichi Newspaper (main writer, and later president) and became very famous as a journalist.
After he came back to Japan, in 1874, he entered a government-controlled newspaper company, Tokyo Nichinichi Newspaper (main writer, and later president) and became very famous as a journalist.

sen.j: また東京府府議会も務めて政界にも進出した。
sen.e: In addition, he also appeared in a political arena as a member of Tokyo Prefectural Assembly.
In addition, he also appeared in the political arena as a member of Tokyo Prefectural Assembly.
In addition, he also appeared in the political arena as a member of Tokyo Prefectural Assembly.

sen.j: 1882年、丸山作楽・水野寅次郎らと共に立憲帝政党を結成し、天皇主権・欽定憲法の施行・制限選挙などを政治要綱に掲げた。
sen.e: In 1882 he established the Constitutional Imperialism Party (立憲帝政党) with Sakura MARUYAMA and Torajiro MIZUNO, holding the principles of policy such as sovereignty of emperor, enforcement of Constitution established by the emperor and election among limited people.
sen.cmt: 立憲帝政党の定訳不明です。
sen.e: In 1882 he established the Constitutional Imperialism Party (立憲帝政党) with Sakura MARUYAMA and Torajiro MIZUNO, holding the principles of policy such as sovereignty of the Emperor, enforcement of Constitution established by the Emperor and election among limited people.
sen.cmt: 冠詞挿入、大文字化しました。
sen.e: In 1882 he established the Constitutional Imperialism Party (立憲帝政党) with Sakura MARUYAMA and Torajiro MIZUNO, holding the principles of policy such as sovereignty of the Emperor, enforcement of Constitution established by the Emperor and election among limited people.

sen.j: 自由党_(日本)や立憲改進党に対抗する政府与党を目指し、士族や商人らの支持を受けた。
sen.e: It aimed to become a ruling party which opposed to the Liberal Party or the Constitutional Progressive Party, and was supported by warrior class and merchant class.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It aimed to become a ruling party which opposed to the Liberal Party or the Constitutional Progressive Party, and was supported by the warrior class and the merchant class.
It aimed to become a ruling party which opposed to the Liberal Party or the Constitutional Progressive Party, and was supported by the warrior class and the merchant class.

sen.j: が、政府が超然主義を採ったため存在意義を失い、翌年に解党した。
sen.e: However, since the government adopted the doctrine of superiority, it lost the significance of existence, so that it dismissed in the following year.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, since the government adopted the doctrine of superiority, it lost the significance of existence, so it dismissed in the following year.
However, since the government adopted the doctrine of superiority, it lost the significance of existence, so it dismissed in the following year.

sen.j: 1888年には経営不振から東京日日新聞社を退社となった。
sen.e: In 1888 he resigned Tokyo Nichinichi Newspaper company because of the slumping business.
In 1888 he resigned Tokyo Nichinichi Newspaper company because of the slumping business.
In 1888 he resigned Tokyo Nichinichi Newspaper company because of the slumping business.

sen.j: その後の福地は条野採菊のやまと新聞の顧問に迎えられて評論活動を続けながら、次第に演劇改良運動とそれを実践する劇場の開設に執念を燃やすようになる。
sen.e: After that, while Fukuchi became an adviser of Yamato Shinbun (newspaper company) of Saigiku JONO and continued critical activity, he had gradually devoted himself in Engeki kairyo undo (theatrical performance improvement movement) and an establishment of a theater where it would be played.

After that, while Fukuchi became an adviser of Yamato Shinbun (newspaper company) of Saigiku JONO and continued critical activity, he had gradually devoted himself to Engeki kairyo undo (theatrical performance improvement movement) and establishment of theaters where it would be played.
sen.cmt: 前置詞変更、冠詞削除、複数化しました。
sen.e: After that, while Fukuchi became an adviser of Yamato Shinbun (newspaper company) of Saigiku JONO and continued critical activity, he had gradually devoted himself to Engeki kairyo undo (theatrical performance improvement movement) and establishment of theaters where it would be played.

sen.j: 1889年11月には千葉勝五郎とともに、東京の木挽町に歌舞伎座を開設した。
sen.e: On November 1889, he opened Kabuki-za Theater at Kobiki-cho, Tokyo with Katsugoro CHIBA.
In November 1889, he opened Kabuki-za Theater at Kobiki-cho, Tokyo with Katsugoro CHIBA.
In November 1889, he opened Kabuki-za Theater at Kobiki-cho, Tokyo with Katsugoro CHIBA.

sen.j: 福地はまもなく経営から離れ、歌舞伎座の座付作者に専念。
sen.e: Fukuchi soon left from the management and devoted himself in writing scripts for Kabuki-za Theater.
Fukuchi soon left the management and devoted himself to writing scripts for Kabuki-za Theater.
sen.cmt: 前置詞削除＆変更しました。
sen.e: Fukuchi soon left the management and devoted himself to writing scripts for Kabuki-za Theater.

sen.j: 活歴物や舞踊などの脚本を多数執筆し、名優市川團十郎 (9代目)らがこれを演じた。
sen.e: He wrote many scripts of katsurekimono (a kind of history play) and dance, which were played by a famous actor Danjuro ICHIKAWA (9th) and so on.
He wrote many scripts of katsurekimono (a kind of history play) and dance, which were played by a famous actor Danjuro ICHIKAWA (ninth) and so on.
sen.cmt: 数字の文字化しました。
sen.e: He wrote many scripts of katsurekimono (a kind of history play) and dance, which were played by a famous actor Danjuro ICHIKAWA (ninth) and so on.

sen.j: 代表作は『大森彦七』『侠客春雨傘』『鏡獅子』『春日局』など。
sen.e: His major works were "Hikoshichi OMORI," "Otokodate Harusame Gasa (A Chivalrous Commoner and a Spring Rain Umbrella)," "Kagamijishi" (The Lion Dance), "Kasuga no tsubone" and so on.
His major works were "Hikoshichi OMORI," "Otokodate Harusame Gasa (A Chivalrous Commoner and a Spring Rain Umbrella)," "Kagamijishi" (The Lion Dance), "Kasuga no tsubone" and so on.
His major works were "Hikoshichi OMORI," "Otokodate Harusame Gasa (A Chivalrous Commoner and a Spring Rain Umbrella)," "Kagamijishi" (The Lion Dance), "Kasuga no tsubone" and so on.

sen.j: 1903年、市川團十郎が死去すると、舞台から手を引いた。
sen.e: After Danjuro ICHIKAWA died in 1903, he left from the stage.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After Danjuro ICHIKAWA died in 1903, he left the stage.
After Danjuro ICHIKAWA died in 1903, he left the stage.

sen.j: 1904年衆議院に立候補して当選を果たすが、この時には既にかつてのような社会的影響力は失われていた。
sen.e: He run for the election of House of Representatives in 1904 and won a seat, but he had already lost an influence on society in the past.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: He run for the election of House of Representatives in 1904 and won a seat, but he had already lost influence on society in the past.
He run for the election of House of Representatives in 1904 and won a seat, but he had already lost influence on society in the past.
In 1906 he died at the age of 64.
In 1906 he died at the age of 64.
In 1906 he died at the age of 64.

tit.cmt: スペルミス訂正しました。

sen.j: 源一郎の文化面における功績は大きく、多くの著作を残している。
sen.e: Genichiro contributed much to culture and left many literally works.
Genichiro contributed much to culture and left many literary works.
sen.cmt: スペルミス訂正しました。
sen.e: Genichiro contributed much to culture and left many literary works.

sen.j: 福澤諭吉と並んで「天下の双福」と称された。
sen.e: He was called 'Sofuku of Japan' with Yukichi FUKUZAWA.
He was called 'Sofuku of Japan' along with Yukichi FUKUZAWA.
He was called 'Sofuku of Japan' along with Yukichi FUKUZAWA.

sen.j: 幕府衰亡論（1883年） 平凡社東洋文庫84 1967年、オンデマンド版で購入可能
sen.e: "Bakufu Suiboron" (the collapse of bakufu) (1883) Heibonsha, Toyo bunko No.84 published in 1967, on-demand edition is available.
"Bakufu Suiboron" (the collapse of bakufu) (1883) Heibonsha, Toyo bunko No.84 published in 1967, on-demand edition is available.
"Bakufu Suiboron" (the collapse of bakufu) (1883) Heibonsha, Toyo bunko No.84 published in 1967, on-demand edition is available.

sen.j: 懐往事談（1895年）
sen.e: "Kaio-jidan" (Reminiscences)(1895)
sen.cmt: 懐往事談の定訳不明です。
sen.e: "Kaio-jidan" (Reminiscences)(1895)
"Kaio-jidan" (Reminiscences)(1895)

sen.j: 幕末政治家（1900年） 平凡社東洋文庫501 1989年、岩波文庫 2003年
sen.e: "Bakumatsu Seijika" (Politicians at the end of the Edo period) (1900) Heibonsha, Toyo bunko No.501 published in 1989, Iwanami bunko published in 2003.
"Bakumatsu Seijika" (Politicians in the end of the Edo period) (1900) Heibonsha, Toyo bunko No.501 published in 1989, Iwanami bunko, published in 2003.
sen.cmt: 前置詞変更、コンマ挿入しました。
sen.e: "Bakumatsu Seijika" (Politicians in the end of the Edo period) (1900) Heibonsha, Toyo bunko No.501 published in 1989, Iwanami bunko, published in 2003.

sen.j: 明治文学全集11「福地桜痴集」柳田泉編、筑摩書房、1966年：「幕府衰亡論」「懐往事談」ほかを収む。
sen.e: "Meiji Bungaku Zenshu 11" (The Collections of Literature in the Meiji period) 'The collection of Ochi FUKUCHI' edited by Izumi YANAGIDA, published by Chikuma Shobo Publishers in 1966, which includes 'Bakufu Suiboron,' 'Kaio-jidan' and so on.
